SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<headline>
Greece Passes Austerity Laws In Critical Vote
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="Seamus L" datetime="2015-07-15T20:24:00">
The reforms, including tax hikes and pensions, were backed, despite significant opposition inside the prime minister's left-wing Syriza party.
The bill had to pass in order for Greece to start negotiations with creditors on a third bailout worth €86bn (£61bn) over three years.

But the reforms will condemn the Greek people to more years of economic hardship. <a href="http://news.sky.com/story/1519707/greece-passes-austerity-laws-in-critical-vote" target="_blank">http://news.sky.com/story/1519707/gr...-critical-vote</a>
This is tragic ! Hope the Greeks kick out the government.
</post>
<post id="p2" author="Theo520" datetime="2015-07-15T20:36:00">
<quote orig_author="Seamus L">
"The reforms, including tax hikes and pensions, were backed, despite significant opposition inside the prime minister's left-wing Syriza party.
The bill had to pass in order for Greece to start negotiations with creditors on a third bailout worth €86bn (£61bn) over three years.

But the reforms will condemn the Greek people to more years of economic hardship. <a href=""http://news.sky.com/story/1519707/greece-passes-austerity-laws-in-critical-vote"" target=""_blank"">http://news.sky.com/story/1519707/gr...-critical-vote</a>
This is tragic ! Hope the Greeks kick out the government."
</quote>
How do you imagine the other route somehow magically sidestepped more years of economic hardship.

Perhaps leaving the EU would have been smart, but it would not be without significant pain. The Govt would still need to cut spending and increase taxes. A lower value currency would make imported items much more of a luxury for the common man, this includes basic food stuffs, medicine, etc.
They would also still need to borrow foreign capital, but at junk bond rates.
</post>
<post id="p3" author="Latias" datetime="2015-07-15T20:42:00">
<quote orig_author="Theo520">
How do you imagine the other route somehow magically sidestepped more years of economic hardship.

Perhaps leaving the EU would have been smart, but it would not be without significant pain. The Govt would still need to cut spending and increase taxes. A lower value currency would make imported items much more of a luxury for the common man, this includes basic food stuffs, medicine, etc.
They would also still need to borrow foreign capital, but at junk bond rates.
</quote>

The lower drachma isn't much of a concern to me, since it would not negatively affect production, but it would make their good more competitive. It is that Greece may still need loans, and it would unlikely have those loans denominated in drachmas.
Perhaps, the real fear would not only be that Portugal and Spain would follow Greece out of the Euro, but that Greece would impose capital controls on their currency.
I would have preferred the Grexit though. There was to be no free lunch for Greece.
</post>
<post id="p4" author="Tomdstone" datetime="2015-07-15T23:25:00">
<quote orig_author="Theo520">
How do you imagine the other route somehow magically sidestepped more years of economic hardship. .
</quote>
With an exit they would have had their own currency and could adjust its value to suit their financial situation.
</post>
<post id="p5" author="Theo520" datetime="2015-07-16T00:59:00">
<quote orig_author="Tomdstone">
With an exit they would have had their own currency and could adjust its value to suit their financial situation.
</quote>

being able to devalue your currency changes how and where the pain is felt, but it doesn't make it go away. Instead of a 10% cut in pension payments, inflation raises your living costs a similar amount
</post>
<post id="p6" author="Latias" datetime="2015-07-16T01:00:00">
<quote orig_author="Theo520">

being able to devalue your currency changes how and where the pain is felt, but it doesn't make it go away. Instead of a 10% cut in pension payments, inflation raises your living costs a similar amount
</quote>
That could be ameliorated through import substitution.
</post>
<post id="p7" author="Tomdstone" datetime="2015-07-16T01:43:00">
<quote orig_author="Theo520">

being able to devalue your currency changes how and where the pain is felt, but it doesn't make it go away. Instead of a 10% cut in pension payments, inflation raises your living costs a similar amount
</quote>
Devaluing the currency can lead to more reliance on products made in Greece and thereby improve the Greek economy.
</post>
<post id="p8" author="Jinglebelle" datetime="2015-07-16T04:40:00">
It still has to go before about 19 other parliaments in europe and be passed,good luck with finland and another six
</post>
<post id="p9" author="ephesians4" datetime="2015-07-16T06:08:00">
<quote orig_author="Seamus L">
"The reforms, including tax hikes and pensions, were backed, despite significant opposition inside the prime minister's left-wing Syriza party.
The bill had to pass in order for Greece to start negotiations with creditors on a third bailout worth €86bn (£61bn) over three years.

But the reforms will condemn the Greek people to more years of economic hardship. <a href=""http://news.sky.com/story/1519707/greece-passes-austerity-laws-in-critical-vote"" target=""_blank"">http://news.sky.com/story/1519707/gr...-critical-vote</a>
This is tragic ! Hope the Greeks kick out the government."
</quote>
What exactly is opposition to austerity?
Nobody likes hardship as a consequence of excessive borrowing.

Dressing it up as "austerity" and opposing it as if it's an ideology anyone else supports is a nonsensical, dishonest thing to do, it is akin to blaming the other side or the rich for gravity and protesting against it, and it is about time politicians stopped this ridiculous exercise in fantasy and denial and started looking, sincerely and intelligently at how to reduce the debt, to "do austerity", without too many people dying.
</post>
<post id="p10" author="frangiuliano115" datetime="2015-07-16T06:32:00">
Hello Seamus L
I couldn't agree with you more. I live in Europe and undersand very well what is going on.

Many economists will tell you that it's possible to leave the E.U. without too much "pain" as it's being called on this thread, but it would have to be planned at least 6 months ahead, local currency would have to be printed, etc etc. I don't know too much about financial things.

What I do know is that not only the Greeks but ALL OF EUROPE is hurting and this grand experiment for which we are paying si NOT working. Mr. Prodi himself, who worked really hard to get Italy into the EU and which we paid for, has said that it is not what had been envisioned.

America came into existance FIRST then came the dollar. Here they made the EURO first and then tried to get together on the other fronts: polotical, social, etc. What a joke. Is everyone aware of how each European country is very very natinaolistic??

People in Greece are not EATING like they used to. How much more austerity can they put up with. Yes, it IS austerity. Being forced upon us. Europe can't print money. Where the heck is it going to come from if everyone is losing their job?
There must be something to this we can't really understand.
All I ask is: Were we (Europe) better off 14 years ago or Now???
14 years ago!!

Yeah. 2/3 of the people voted for Tsipras to get them the heck out of the Union. It just wasn't planned right as I said before. No wonder Varoufakis, Finance Minister, quit. He knew what was coming and didn't want to be a part of it.
God bless you all - such intelligent comments
Fran
</post>
<post id="p11" author="Ridgerunner" datetime="2015-07-16T11:40:00">
It's hard not to be of two minds about this.
First of all, Greece is not going to pay all the money back, and Germany is going to have to accept that fact if it hasn't already. This has a "lipstick on a pig" sort of appearance to it.
Secondly, Greece is going to have a severe downscaling in its economy whether it stays in the Eurozone or not.

Third, and this is not the easiest thing to say. For decades and decades and decades prior to the formation of the EU, (and excepting WWI, WWII and their immediate aftermaths) Germany and the north were relatively wealthy while Greece and much of southern Europe were far from it. Perhaps it's inevitable that things return to their more "normal" state in Europe, historically speaking. I have no ability to say why it was that way through most of the 19th and 20th Centuries, only that it was. The EU promised to be a mechanism to spread prosperity throughout the union. But if it can only be done through the use of national credit cards that eventually come due, it's not worth having.
</post>
<post id="p12" author="Theo520" datetime="2015-07-16T12:58:00">
<quote orig_author="frangiuliano115">
Hello Seamus L
I couldn't agree with you more. I live in Europe and undersand very well what is going on.

Many economists will tell you that it's possible to leave the E.U. without too much "pain" as it's being called on this thread, but it would have to be planned at least 6 months ahead, local currency would have to be printed, etc etc. I don't know too much about financial things.

What I do know is that not only the Greeks but ALL OF EUROPE is hurting and this grand experiment for which we are paying si NOT working. Mr. Prodi himself, who worked really hard to get Italy into the EU and which we paid for, has said that it is not what had been envisioned.

There must be something to this we can't really understand.
All I ask is: Were we (Europe) better off 14 years ago or Now???
14 years ago!!

Yeah. 2/3 of the people voted for Tsipras to get them the heck out of the Union. It just wasn't planned right as I said before. No wonder Varoufakis, Finance Minister, quit. He knew what was coming and didn't want to be a part of it.
God bless you all - such intelligent comments
Fran
</quote>
Fran, if the EU is failing it's not because of a single currency. The likely cause is the EU mandated overhead and excess restrictions that stifle business and entrepreneurship.

While the act of leaving the EU may not be painful, it doesn't cure all underlying economic ills that exist in a country. It's not like someone who is riddled with cancer suddenly get the body of a 21 yr old. A new currency isn't a magic pill.
</post>
<post id="p13" author="Vouthon" datetime="2015-07-16T13:54:00">
<quote orig_author="Ridgerunner">
"It's hard not to be of two minds about this.
First of all, Greece is not going to pay all the money back, and Germany is going to have to accept that fact if it hasn't already. This has a ""lipstick on a pig"" sort of appearance to it.
Secondly, Greece is going to have a severe downscaling in its economy whether it stays in the Eurozone or not.

Third, and this is not the easiest thing to say. For decades and decades and decades prior to the formation of the EU, (and excepting WWI, WWII and their immediate aftermaths) Germany and the north were relatively wealthy while Greece and much of southern Europe were far from it. Perhaps it's inevitable that things return to their more ""normal"" state in Europe, historically speaking. I have no ability to say why it was that way through most of the 19th and 20th Centuries, only that it was. The EU promised to be a mechanism to spread prosperity throughout the union. But if it can only be done through the use of national credit cards that eventually come due, it's not worth having."
</quote>
Interesting post and points.

The Eurozone crisis is as much a crisis of "identity" as it one of economics. It has intensified deep-rooted debates concerning the nature of European integration and the question of whether there are fundamental cultural differences inhibiting true solidarity from taking shape in the Union.

In an ironic sense, the Euro is actually dividing Europe by means of a common currency the continent may well not be ready for. A common currency throughout the North/North-West and East (ie Germany, Netherlands, France, Finland, Sweden, Poland, the Baltics etc.) would likely be far more efficient since there is a greater commonality in fiscal thinking among these Member States.
The crisis is indeed revealing starkly apposite cultural characteristics along the North/South divide, especially latitude versus rectitude in handling money.
German finance has, from the medieval era of the Hanseatic League, been far more circumspect and exact than Italian, Spanish or indeed Greek approaches to "money" and "debt" related issues.

The fascinating thing is that "New Europe", the former Soviet East that endured brutal devaluation in currency as these countries made painful transitions to free-market economies, are invariably found to be in serious wont of sympathy towards Greece. The primary advocates for the Greek plight (other than the fact that everyone with a heart empathises with the immense hardship endured by the Greek populace themselves) are to be found among their fellow Southern neighbours in Spain (where the far-left Podemos Party is attempting something similar to Syriza) and in Italy.

Eastern Europe is effectively "New Northern Europe" and these states have a gained a new diplomatic confidence from their membership in the Union. The President of the European Council is now a Pole, for instance.
Consider:
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/live/greek-debt-crisis-live-updates/little-sympathy-for-greece-in-parts-of-eastern-europe/" target="_blank">http://www.nytimes.com/live/greek-de...astern-europe/</a>
Quote:
<b>Little Sympathy for Greece in Eastern Europe<b>

<b>Lithuania and other former Communist states in the region have all had to put in place austerity measures at some point since the fall of the Berlin Wall more than 25 years ago.<b> Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania did so comparatively recently, after the global financial crisis set off deep recessions there in 2008 and 2009.

<b>Latvia was hit particularly hard,<b>as its gross domestic product shrank nearly a quarter over two years and it entered the world’s deepest recession at the time. The country fiercely tightened its fiscal policy to qualify for an international bailout and to avert bankruptcy. <b><u>Since then, it has joined the eurozone and become one of the fastest-growing economies in the European Union.<u><b>

Alluding to Latvia’s success with strict austerity measures, <b><u>Janis Reirs, the Latvian finance minister, told journalists in Brussels on Tuesday, “Latvian people do not understand the Greek people.”...<u><b>

Rafal Trzaskowski, the Polish minister for European affairs, said on state radio on Wednesday that Poland, like other countries in the region, would demand “tough reforms” from Greece at the European Union summit meeting scheduled for Sunday.
Also from a few years back:
<a href="http://www.policy-network.net/pno_detail.aspx?ID=4459&amp;title=A-perfect-storm-Europes-growing-North-South-divide" target="_blank">http://www.policy-network.net/pno_de...h-South-divide</a>
Quote:

<b>Citizens of Southern Europe now have substantially less trust in government, trust in political parties, and satisfaction with democracy than those in the North.<b>allied with shifting political attitudes, this breach is likely to lead to <b><u>increasingly polarised views, creating a new economic and territorial cleavage in Europe between north and south<u><b>

<b>Some weeks ago Lluis Orriols wrote an interesting article about the emerging “ideological divorce” in Europe between the so-called PIIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece and Spain) and the rest of the EU countries. While the former are increasingly moving to the left, the rest of Europe is gradually moving to the right.<b>
</post>
<post id="p14" author="FollowChrist34" datetime="2015-07-16T14:10:00">
<quote orig_author="Vouthon">
Interesting post and points.

The Eurozone crisis is as much a crisis of "identity" as it one of economics. It has intensified deep-rooted debates concerning the nature of European integration and the question of whether there are fundamental cultural differences inhibiting true solidarity from taking shape in the Union.

In an ironic sense, the Euro is actually dividing Europe by means of a common currency the continent may well not be ready for. A common currency throughout the North/North-West and East (ie Germany, Netherlands, France, Finland, Sweden, Poland, the Baltics etc.) would likely be far more efficient since there is a greater commonality in fiscal thinking among these Member States.
The crisis is indeed revealing starkly apposite cultural characteristics along the North/South divide, especially latitude versus rectitude in handling money.
German finance has, from the medieval era of the Hanseatic League, been far more circumspect and exact than Italian, Spanish or indeed Greek approaches to "money" and "debt" related issues.

The fascinating thing is that "New Europe", the former Soviet East that endured brutal devaluation in currency as these countries made painful transitions to free-market economies, are invariably found to be in serious wont of sympathy towards Greece. The primary advocates for the Greek plight (other than the fact that everyone with a heart empathises with the immense hardship endured by the Greek populace themselves) are to be found among their fellow Southern neighbours in Spain (where the far-left Podemos Party is attempting something similar to Syriza) and in Italy.

Eastern Europe is effectively "New Northern Europe" and these states have a gained a new diplomatic confidence from their membership in the Union. The President of the European Council is now a Pole, for instance.
Consider:
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/live/greek-debt-crisis-live-updates/little-sympathy-for-greece-in-parts-of-eastern-europe/" target="_blank">http://www.nytimes.com/live/greek-de...astern-europe/</a>
</quote>

It doesn't surprise me at all that these divisions are surfacing. I think it was perhaps somewhat naive to think that they would be buried in a Eurozone Utopialand in the first place. Austerity measures are inevitable, but that is not to say I don't sympathize with Greece. Frankly, I think all of us in these "wealthy" and/or "not so wealthy" Western countries are suffering more or less. Compared to the 90s I am just holding on and I am in the good ole USA. Very scary. The US debt stands at $18 trillion (much of it owed to China and Japan). I don't think there is any country out there hording its wealth, Scrooge-like, unfortunately. And again, along with the Greeks, I do also feel for the Germans who make up the balance of their debt - the taxpayers. What kind of justice is that for them.
</post>
<post id="p15" author="crai7" datetime="2015-07-16T15:04:00">

Germany perhaps still has a shred of the Protestant work ethic, along with the UK and possibly the USA. I think this will continue to erode as the last echoes of religious belief fade. Instead of merit based capitalist systems combined with religious morals, you have atheism, socialism, relativism and feminism - all destructive forces. France, Italy and Spain never really had much of a work ethic, Greece is just further along.
</post>
</doc>
